dataset.title: MCR LTER: Coral Reef: pH Time Series from Bottom-mounted SeaFET on the Fringing Reef, January-February 2011

abstract.para: Bottom-mounted instrumentation (SeaFET, Seabird thermistors) sampled for 6 weeks on the fringing reef of Moorea Island, French Polynesia at site LTER Fringe 1. Sampling began in January 2011. The instruments were secured to a cement piling at 3.3 meters depth and 0.7 meters above the sandy bottom. The SeaFET recorded voltages from a thermistor and pH electrodes at a 10-minute sampling interval. Discrete seawater samples were collected using a Niskin bottle during the deployment; pH, salinity, and total alkalinity of this sample were measured to calculate seawater pH (total scale) from raw SeaFET data as well as other carbonate chemistry parameters. The Seabird thermistors provided measures of seawater temperature at 10-minute sampling intervals.

These data are published in Rivest, E.B. and G.E. Hofmann. 2014. Responses of the metabolism of the larvae of Pocillopora damicornis to ocean acidification and warming. PLoS ONE DOI:10.1371/journal.pone.0096172

keywordSet.keyword: Richard B. Gump South Pacific Research Station

intellectualRights.para:
Data collected under the auspices of the MCR LTER are available to the public after primary publication, or at most two years after the completion of the study unless proprietary restrictions are warranted. Use of MCR LTER data is subject to acceptance of the following conditions:
1. The user agrees to provide valid name and contact information prior to downloading online data. This information will be used to contact the user in case of changes to the data, and may also be used by data set authors and MCR LTER project administrators to document data usage.
2. The user agrees to cite the data set author and MCR LTER in all publications in which the data are used, as per the instructions in the data documentation. If no specific instructions are provided in the data documentation, the user is requested to include the following statement: "Data sets were provided by the Moorea Coral Reef Ecosystem LTER, funded by the US National Science Foundation (OCE-0417412)."
3. The user agrees to provide one copy of any manuscript based on MCR LTER data to the data set author prior to submitting it for publication.
4. The user agrees to send two hard copies of any published manuscript based on MCR LTER data to the following address: Dr. Andrew J. Brooks Deputy Program Director, MCR LTER Marine Science Institute University of California Santa Barbara, CA 93106-6150 The user also agrees to send one electronic copy (pdf format) to the following e-mail address: brooks@msi.ucsb.edu
5. Users are prohibited from selling or redistributing any data provided by MCR LTER without explicit prior permission.
6. Users are encouraged to contact original investigators responsible for data. Where appropriate, researchers whose projects are integrally dependent on MCR LTER data are encouraged to consider collaboration and/or co-authorship with original investigators.
7. Extensive efforts are made to ensure that online data are accurate and up to date, but the authors and the MCR LTER will not take responsibility for any errors that may exist in data provided online. Furthermore, the user assumes all responsibility for errors in analysis or judgment resulting from use of the data.
8. Any violation of the terms of this agreement will result in immediate forfeiture of the data and loss of access privileges to other MCR LTER data sets.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: LTER 1 Fringing Reef, Moorea, French Polynesia

description.para: This is a short-term study, part of a graduate student thesis. This dataset is not expected to be extended in time.
Revision 3 converts data access from Type II to Type I.
Revision 4 only corrects the spelling of Moorea in the abstract.

section.title: Deployment Characteristics
section.para: pH on the fringing reef where the adult P. damicornis colonies were collected was recorded continuously from January 28 to March 19, 2011. An autonomous data logger based on a Honeywell Durafet® pH sensor, called a SeaFET (Martz et al. 2010), was deployed at 17.4803 S 149.7989 W within the MCR LTER Fringe 2 long-term monitoring site. Secured to a cement piling at about 10 ft depth and suspended about 2 feet off the sandy bottom, the SeaFET was configured to measure and average pH voltage over a 30-second period at 10-minute intervals, averaging data collected over a 30-second period. Alongside the SeaFET were deployed two Seabird thermisters, synced with the pH sensor to simultaneously record temperature.

Following deployment, the SeaFET electrodes were allowed to stabilize for several days and were then calibrated using discrete seawater samples collected in situ. This single-point calibration is justified based on sensor characteristics previously demonstrated (Martz et al. 2010). On February 25, 2011, a SCUBA diver using a 5L Niskin bottle collected a single calibration sample adjacent to the SeaFET in concurrence with its voltage reading. Temperature of the seawater was measured using an alcohol thermometer. Two 500 mL water samples from the Niskin were returned to the laboratory on each of the two days, where pH, total alkalinity, and salinity were measured in four replicates (see above) within 1-2 hours of sample collection. AT and salinity values from these two samples were average and used to generate in situ pH and pCO2 values from the continuous pH and temperature data using CO2calc (Robbins et al. 2010). While it is inappropriate and inaccurate to assume that the salinity and total alkalinity remained constant throughout the 2-month deployment, these assumptions provide for a valuable approximate calculation, allowing us to generate one of the first real-time graphs of pCO2 variation over a coral reef.

section.title: Carbonate Chemistry Analyses
section.para: To verify and monitor the physical parameters of the ocean acidification x temperature treatments, the chemistry of the seawater in the aquaria was analyzed daily. pH, temperature, salinity, and total alkalinity of seawater in each aquarium were measured during the incubations.
Carbonate chemistry analyses of calibration samples:

Seawater salinities were measured using a conductivity meter (YSI 3100). Seawater pH was measured using a spectrophotometric method with indicator dye, m-cresol purple (SOP 3b, DOE 1994). Total alkalinity (AT) was measured using an automated, closed-cell potentiometric titration (SOP 6b, Dickson et al. 2007) with a Mettler-Toledo T50 titrator and a DG115-SC pH probe (Mettler-Toledo). The probe was calibrated at three points using pH 4.00, 7.00, and 10.00 NBS buffers (Fisher-Scientific). Titrations were performed using certified acid titrant (~0.1M HCl, 0.6 M NaCl; A. Dickson Laboratory, Scripps Institute of Oceanography). A non-linear least-squares approach was used to calculate AT from the titrant volume and e.m.f. data (Fangue et al. 2010). Certified reference materials (CRMs) from A. Dickson Laboratory, Scripps Institute of Oceanography, were used to determine the accuracy and precision of the titrations daily before experimental samples were measured. For each day of the experiment, analyzed CRMs were accurate within 10 ÃŽÂ¼mol kg-1. pH at 25Ã‚Â°C, AT, temperature, and salinity were used to calculate the pH and pCO2 of the treatments using CO2calc (Robbins et al. 2010), with COÃ‚Â­2 constants K1, K2 from Mehrbach et al. 1973 refit by Dickson and Millero, 1987 and pH expressed on the total scale (mol kg-SW-1).

section.title: Data Calculations
section.para: pH time series data were calculated from raw data from the SeaFET sensor using an Excel template from Todd Martz (see below) as well as the seawater pH and salinity from the calibration sample (reference SeaFET pH Calculations Table). pH (SeaFET) and temperature (thermistor) time series data were smoothed using a 1-hour low-pass filter in Excel (reference SeaFET pH Filtered Time Series Table). These smoothed time series as well as salinity and total alkalinity values from the calibration were used as input for CO2CALC, which derived time series for the complete carbonate chemistry system for this deployment (reference CO2CALC Output Table).

section.title: Constants for SeaFET pH Calculations
section.para: Constants used to derive data in the data table "SeaFET pH Calculations"

listitem.para: Thermisor Values: Constants based on SeaFET thermister that are used to derive temperature In degrees Celsius from Vtherm
Ts: Constant not used in calculations
Vout: Constant not used in calculations
dE/dt(INT): Temperature dependence of EÃ‚Â°(INT) at one atm (Martz 2010)
dE/dt(EXT): Temperature dependence of EÃ‚Â°(EXT) at one atm (Martz 2010)

section.title: pH SampleCalc 2: Directions for use of excel tempalte from Todd Martz for SeaFET

listitem.para: Paste values from datafile into col B-F (SeaFET) or B-Z (SeapHOx) beginning on line 12. Status should be "deployed" except for row corresponding to the descrete sample taken, which should be labled "discrete sample taken"
Direct values in cells B11-F11 (pH standardization) to the line corresponding to a discrete sample
Highlight discrete sample line for your reference
Enter the pH and salinity of the discrete sample in cells AF11 and AG11 (if using SBE37 Salinity, direct AG11 to highlighted value in Col AG)
Verify that the pH value returned in column AF and AT on the line corresponding to the discrete sample match the value entered into cell AF11
Direct Col AB to V to use SBE37 temp for pH calcs (or apply a const. offset to durafet temp to improve accuracy)
Copy and paste formulas down in columns AA-BC

section.para: Note: This data set used an earlier version of Todd Martz's spreadsheet which did not include SeapHOx
Martz Lab at Scripps Institution of Oceanography http://martzlab.ucsd.edu/research/SeaFET.html
get CO2CALC link. Get any/all relevant SOPs.

section.title: CO2calc
section.para: The program was written by L.L. Robins. If you use CO2calc for calculations, please, cite the program as:

Robbins, L.L., Hansen, M.E., Kleypas, J.A., and Meylan, S.C., 2010, CO2calcÃ¢Â€Â”A user-friendly seawater carbon calculator for Windows, Max OS X, and iOS (iPhone): U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 2010Ã¢Â€Â“1280, 17 p.

CO2calc calculates the Revelle factor and the saturation states for aragonite and calcite if two of the parameters are provided along with temperature, pressure, total phosphate concentration, and total silicate concentration. The five inorganic carbon parameters are: :
TA = total alkalinity
TCO2 = total inorganic carbon
pH = acidity
pCO2 = partial pressure of CO2
fCO2 = fugacity of CO2

dataTable.entityDescription: SeaFET raw voltage data input and calibrated pH, temperature and other output.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Notes on deployment status. The calibration row is "standardization".

codeDefinition.definition: A special row of data used to set the calibration constants.
The timestamp coincident with the bottle sample collection for calibration.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Date and time as YYYY-MM-DD hh:mm:ss in UTC recorded by the instrument, set just before deployment.
Instrument battery voltage. An indication of instrument behavior.
Thermistor voltage raw data used to calculate seawater temperature.
Voltage of the internal ISFET electrode. Vout (FET|INT). This is the data actually used to calculate seawater pH.
Voltage of the reference external ISFET electrode. Vrs (FET|EXT). This is used for quality control.
Greenwich mean time. In this dataset UTC is set on the instrument so this column is not used.
Cumulative voltage of all 6 batteries. Voltage of one battery, multiplied by 6. Used only as a quality control.
Thermistor resistance raw data
Temperature of seawater, calibrated in Celsius
Temperature of seawater, calibrated in Kelvin
Slope of the Nernst equation used to calculate Eo(INT)

Standard potential of internal reference. Eo(INT) (T, P); a characteristic of the two half cells forming the circuit and depends on temperature and pressure but not on the concentration of the analyte.
pH of seawater calibrated on Total Scale using internal reference electrode

Salinity of seawater. This can be data from a co-deployed conductivity sensor (time series) or in this case it is the salinity measured from the discrete bottle sample that is assumed for all time points.
The concentration of ions in seawater in moles per kilogram seawater.
Total sulfate at the given salinity in units of moles per kilogram of seawater
Concentration of chloride ions in moles per kilogram of seawater
Equilibrium constant of HSO4 in moles per kilogram of seawater
pH of seawater on free scale using internal reference electrode
Debye Huckel constant
Mean activity coefficient of HCl in seawater, depends on the ionic strength, charge number(s) and the Debye-Huckel Constant
Inverse of KHSO4 in units of kilograms of seawater per mole of SO4
Concentration of free hydrogen ions in units of moles per kilograms seawater
free hydrogen ion and chloride ion activity; the "effective concentration" of these species in the mixture
Standard potential of external reference. Eo(INT) (T, P); a characteristic of the two half cells forming the circuit and depds on temperature and pressure but not on the concentration of the analyte
pH of seawater measured by the external electrode; on the free hydrogen ion scale
pH of seawater measured by the external electrode; on the total scale
A quality control measure, pHtot(EXT) - pHtot(INT); difference between external and internal electrode measurements of seawater pH

dataTable.entityDescription: SeaFET calibrated pH smoothed with a low-pass filter one hour running average.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Date and time in YYYY-MM-DD hh:mm:ss format recorded on instrument.
Calibrated pH on Total Scale from internal duraFET.
One hour running average low-pass filter smoothed values of calibrated pH on Total Scale.

dataTable.entityDescription: Input and derived output data for the seawater carbonate chemistry system

attribute.attributeDefinition: Identifier for sample created by user
Alternative name for sample created by user
Time when sample was collected in hh:mm:ss format recorded on instrument.
Date sample was collected in YYYY-MM-DD format recorded on instrument.
Latitude coordinate of deployment site in decimal degrees
Longitude coordinate of deployment site in decimal degrees
Salinity of seawater under input conditions; in psu
Temperature of the seawater when the pH was measured; this is the input condition; for pH measured in the lab, this should be ~25 degrees Celsius
Input hydrostatic pressure in dbars (surface=0)
Total concentration of phosphorus in seawater under input conditions; micromol per kilogram seawater
Total concentration of silicate in seawater under input conditions; micromol per kilogram seawater
Total alkalinity of seawater under input conditions; micromol per kilogram seawater
Total CO2 of seawater under input conditions; micromol per kilogram seawater
pH in the scale chosen in the column named "pH Scale"
Fugosity of CO2 in wet (100% saturated) air which is in equilibrium with the water in microatmospheres
Partial pressure of CO2 is the product of the mole fraction of CO2 in wet air and the total pressure in microatmospheres
Concentration of bicarbonate ion under input conditions; micromol per kilogram seawater
Concentration of carbonate ion under input conditions; micromol per kilogram seawater
Concentraiton of CO2 under input conditions; micromol per kilogram seawater
Alkalinity of boron under input conditions; micromol per kilogram seawater
Concentration of hydroxide ions under input conditions; micromol per kilogram seawater
Alkalinity of phosphorus under input conditions; micromol per kilogram seawater
Alkalinity of silicate under input conditions; micromol per kilogram seawater
Homogeneous buffer factor under input conditions; the percent change in fCO2 or pCO2 caused by a 1% change in total carbon at constant alkalinity; no units
Omega calcite, calcite saturation state under input conditions; no units
Omega aragonite, aragonite saturation state under input conditions; no units
Mole fraction of CO2 in dry air at 1 atm under input conditions; parts per million dry at 1 atm
Output temperature; temperature of the seawater when the sample was collected; degrees Celsius
Output hydrostatic pressure in dbars (surface=0)
Output pH, calculated for output salinity and temperature; total scale
Fugacity of CO2 under output conditions; microatmospheres
Partial pressure of CO2 under output conditions; microatmospheres
Concentration of bicarbonate ion under output conditions; micromol per kilogram seawater
Concentration of carbonate ion under output conditions; micromol per kilogram seawater
Concentraiton of CO2 under output conditions; micromol per kilogram seawater
Alkalinity of boron under output conditions; micromol per kilogram seawater
Concentration of hydroxide ions under output conditions; micromol per kilogram seawater

Alkalinity of silicate under output conditions; micromol per kilogram seawater
Homogeneous buffer factor under output conditions; the percent change in fCO2 or pCO2 caused by a 1% change in total carbon at constant alkalinity; no units
Omega calcite, calcite saturation state under output conditions; no units
Omega aragonite, aragonite saturation state under output conditions; no units
Mole fraction of CO2 in dry air at 1 atm under output conditions; parts per million dry at 1 atm
Concentration of CO2 in atmospheric air; in microatmospheres
Wind speed at time of sample collection; in knots or meters per second
Flux of CO2 between air and sea under input conditions; in millimole per square meter per day
Flux of CO2 between air and sea under output conditions; in millimole per square meter per day
Dissociation constants selected by user. (This dataset uses K1, K2 from Hansson, 1973 refit by Dickson and Millero, 1987 exclusively.)
